title: 110_hr1290
content: The "Biosurveillance Enhancement Act of 2007" is also known as the National Biosurveillance Integration Center, which is added as a new section to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The National Biosurveillance Integration Center (NBIC) is established by the Secretary to enhance the Federal Government's ability to quickly identify and localize biological events by integrating data from various sources. The NBIC includes an Integrated Biosurveillance Network to detect biological events that pose a risk to the United States or its key assets by consolidating data from different surveillance systems. The National Biosurveillance Integration Center (NBIC) uses private and public sources to identify biological events in real-time. The Director is responsible for monitoring data feeds, improving analytical methods, and enhancing overall performance of the NBIC. The NBIC, under the Director's oversight, establishes procedures for reporting suspicious events, receives homeland security information, and provides technical assistance to government and private entities. The Director continuously evaluates data for biological events and integrates it with NBIC data for overall situational awareness. The NBIC, overseen by the Director, provides integrated information to relevant government entities, notifies them of significant biological events, and shares real-time communication with the National Operations Center. The Director oversees the NBIC, which provides integrated information to government entities and shares real-time communication with the National Operations Center. The Secretary seeks to enter into agreements with other federal departments and agencies for information sharing. Under agreements with various federal departments and agencies, the NBIC aims to integrate biosurveillance information capabilities, receive timely data for biological situational awareness, and establish connectivity for data systems. The NBIC integrates biosurveillance information capabilities, receives timely data for biological situational awareness, and establishes connectivity for data systems. The Secretary ensures the Director is notified of homeland security information on significant biological threats and receives related reports promptly. The NBIC is designated as a public health authority and must comply with privacy regulations, including those of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. It is authorized to collect health information for the purpose of preventing. The NBIC is required to comply with privacy regulations, including the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The Director will establish an interagency working group to enhance biosurveillance capabilities and submit an annual report to Congress. The NBIC is required to provide an annual report to Congress, including a list of participating entities, access schedules, entities with access to integrated information, and implementation plans with cost and milestones. The NBIC annual report to Congress includes details on cost, schedule, key milestones, and status. The Secretary's authority does not affect other departments or agencies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for each fiscal year. A "biological event" is defined as terrorism involving biological agents or a naturally occurring outbreak of infectious disease. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of contents in section 1(b) of such Act is amended to include items related to the title. The National Biosurveillance Integration Center, as mandated by the Homeland Security Act of 2002, must be fully operational by September 30, 2008.
